title: $A recoups losses after Fed minutes
text:
Thu, Aug 20, 2015, 9:22 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 38 mins. $A recoups losses after Fed minutes AAP â€“ 2 hours 2 minutes ago Recommend Print 
The Australian dollar is flat after it bounced back following the release of the minutes of the US Federal Reserve's July policy meeting. 
At 0700 AEST on Thursday, the local unit was trading at 73.50 US cents, slightly down from 73.53 cents on Wednesday. 
The currency steadily lost ground earlier in the offshore session on the back of falling commodity prices, hitting a low of 73.12 US cents. 
But the Australian dollar rallied as much as half a US cent after Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) minutes showed there were doubts about the likelihood of an interest rate hike in September. 
Westpac senior market strategist Imre Speizer said the US dollar fell sharply, which allowed the Australian dollar to rally. 
"The FOMC minutes showed a leaning towards a hike but also that more evidence was needed of economic growth," he said. 
"Conditions for a rate hike were approaching but had not yet been met." 
Mr Speizer expects the Australian dollar to lose ground in the coming months as the US dollar rallies ahead of a interest rate rise. 
CURRENCY SNAPSHOT AT 0700 AEST ON THURSDAY 
One Australian dollar buys: 
* 73.50 US cents, from 73.53 cents on Wednesday 
* 90.98 Japanese yen, from 91.37 yen 
* 66.09 euro cents, from 66.45 euro cents 
* 111.29 New Zealand cents, from 111.56 NZ cents 
* 46.87 British pence, from 46.91 pence 
(*Currency closes taken at 1700 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
